Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 8-12 hours

Early in the semester: 6-7 hours
Pre-midterm report and spring break: 12-15 hours
Early post spring break: 6-8 hours
Final weeks: 12-15 hours

Of course, the caveat for this question (and the following questions) is that different project teams have different schedules and time commitments. Mine only speaks for the project that I was assigned to.
10 hours
>10hrs
At least four hours per week, but as many as 15 during the hardest few weeks of the semester, especially with logging data
depends  but in the second half of the course 3-9 hours
3 hours, but when we were preparing presentations or reports, probably 6 hours.

Pre-spring break ~10 hours per week.
Spring break (10 days) ~ 15 hours per day.
Post-spring break 15-20 hours per week.

This class requires a lot of time. Given the spring break component and amount of time needed to be fully engaged, should be 4 credits not 3, and I think would also benefit from being a year long course.

Class sessions could be more productive. Sometimes I felt as though the times we were actually in class were not all that related to our projects and the presentations were simply used to fill time. I would suggest dedicating more time during class sessions to group meetings, especially in the second half of the semester.

This course was a great learning experience (as you'll read in my personal reflection essay), but I think the workload was too high, especially considering the fact that we had to do fieldwork for 8 days during spring break from 9am to 6pm. The team was very burned out after the break and that affected both our morale and the quality of work in the second half of the semester. Granted, we were told that the expectation was 10 hours of contribution a week, but taking up the entire spring break meant that students had no time to recharge for the second half, especially for the other courses that picked up intensity then. 

I think making this course stretch into two semesters (e.g. AY 2018-19 Semester 2 and AY 2019-2020 Semester 1) would not only protect student welfare, but also improve the quantity and quality of deliverables that we can produce. The first semester could be used for theory research, literature review, etc, and students would take a few days in early/late summer to conduct fieldwork, and then would use the second semester to analyze data and write a proper report. Right now, everything feels very rushed at any given step. If any contingency comes up, there was barely any buffer to deal with them.

This course provides a good opportunity for us to put public health knowledge&skills into practice. However, I think some of the projects need to be better planned. The workload of different projects is not even. Also, I hope the projects&content would be more related to climate change and sustainability, but less focused on environmental justice.

I would rate this course very poorly. While there were many frustrating aspects of this course, I will highlight three. As part of the class, I traveled to Alabama for spring break to conduct fieldwork. We had planned to conduct extensive door-to-door canvassing to administer health surveys. However, community members on the ground advised our team not to go alone because of safety concerns. We were a team of three females. When we informed our professor, I was appalled that she suggested we go anyway; and our team had to describe multiple times the safety concerns community members had/explain why we were not going canvassing. Students should never have to explain/justify multiple times why they are not doing something if they believe it would place their safety at risk, and a professor should certainly not encourage students to do something if they and community members they are working with believe it may place them in harm's way.

I also find it unfortunate that we traveled without petty cash. We incurred many expenses throughout the trip (e.g., for fuel and food), and it took well over a month to receive reimbursements. As a student without an income, that posed financial hardship; and had I known it would have taken so long to receive the reimbursement, I likely would not have gone on the trip. Third, our professor constantly compared our team to another team in the course in front of that other team. She often made it seem like they were doing a better job or glorifying them at our expense, which made the experience quite frustrating. While such comparisons can provide learning opportunities in certain contexts, in this case, the comparisons that were made left us feeling like our work was "less than" or not good enough, and, most often, they were inappropriate.

With that said, the community we were working in was amazing, and having the opportunity to serve there made this experience worthwhile. I would also like to clarify that there are multiple professors for this course, and I did not work with Professor Dubrow, the primary instructor, on this project.

I think the fact that the class is project-oriented is its strength, but sometimes this underlying structure didn't mesh well with the lectures. I felt like we oftentimes spent whole classes focused on one or two topics that were specific just to a single group, and therefore were a little bit of a waste of others' time.
I think that this was an incredible course. I'm not so sure as to how it could be improved.

I liked that most of the course was based on the projects we had chosen and was focused on producing practical output. I would have preferred the lecture half of the class be shortened to give more time with the project groups.

I really enjoyed this course. I loved getting field experience and working with local and state partners outside of the academic environment. I think the class was well structured and I liked hearing about everyone elses projects, as well as about their challenges(so that we could think through how to solve them).  I also liked the presenters/guest lectures for the first half of class and then team meetings in the second half. It gave us just enough time to check in and feel very supported by Professors Dubrow and Engelman-Lado.

This is one of the best classes Ive taken at Yale. Rob and Marianne are both amazing professors in terms of giving engaging lectures relevant to the overall learning objectives of the course, and in their availability/engagement with the student team.

Strengths: 
-Great balance of seminar class and time for project teams to meet. Seminars used to workshop individual team projects were really helpful and also interesting to hear what other teams were working on. 
-Field component over spring break.
-the Professor team

Weaknesses: 
-Limited interaction with Rob because Marianne was the advisor for the project I was working on. Would have loved more of his feedback and input on our project to provide an additional perspective.

I really enjoyed the structure of the course and having a regular meeting time where both Rob and Marianne presented to the class. I think it was also good to hear from other groups on their projects and have the class time to help groups.

Prof. Dubrow is very knowledgeable about the subject of the class and consistently shows his knowledge. His feedback on project materials was helpful and timely. His teaching/could could have been improved by tailoring class sessions to what students want to learn.
Professor Dubrow was extremely helpful and supportive to us. He helped with epidemiological and survey design questions, assisted with logistics, and was always around to answer late-night questions.

Professor Dubrow was very quick and candid about giving us constructive criticism and raising important questions about our project. He was also open to hearing our ideas and rationale behind them as well. He clearly has a wealth of experience and it was great to learn from him.
Very nice guy and much appreciated his willingness to assist with project details

Dr. Dubrow is a really kind and intelligent professor. I appreciated his lectures and especially appreciated the help that he offered us as it related to the development of our survey, data entry, and data interpretation.
Sometimes difficult to read him, but I do think he was trying to help students. Most of the instruction and learning happened between group members as we worked on our projects.

Strengths:
- really open to feedback and making sure the project/class works for us as students
- gave good feedback and was always available whenever we needed guidance or support
- kept us in the loop with what was going to happen in class each week via announcements or other emails
- canvas site was well organized and detailed
- clear expectations were laid out for all assignments, and we were always able to clarify whatever we had questions on

Weaknesses:
- none really. I appreciated Professor Dubrows support and guidance throughout the whole project and felt guided but also like we were an independent team making our own decisions.

Rob is incredibly knowledgable, approachable, and really clear in his expectations.
He is clearly passionate about the subject of the course, and wants students to succeed.
Very prompt in feedback and responding to students.

Rob was really helpful in facilitating conversations between the student team and project preceptors. Conversations could get mired in sticky questions, but Rob was refocus the conversation on the priorities of the project.
I think that Rob was great and provided strong feedback and guidance when asked.

This course was a lot of work and required a lot of work-time outside of the classroom (i.e. about 8-12 hours per week). The professors challenged us to do our best and demanded high quality work.  This being said, the project I worked on was incredibly meaningful and has been very useful to me in my job/internship search. I would recommend this class to another student who is looking to gain professional experience and has room in their schedule to dedicate sufficient time to this course.
Do you want to get your hands dirty on client/community based environmental health research and advocacy work? Then this is the course for you. Warning: sleep deprivation ahead.
I would not recommend this course to another student.
While the main core of the class (the projects) are innately interdisciplinary, the lectures are firmly just about public health related topics
I would summarize this course as a transformative experience, both incredibly theoretical and practically applied. I would state that the work load is intense, but that it is worth it.
I would recommend it for students who want practical work experience that fits into the course/semester setting
Great course to get involved in environmental projects. Not all are climate change related but they are important nonetheless.

Practicum class, meaning its all field based. You work through a problem and project aims with a wonderful team of people with different backgrounds and skillsets in order to meet certain deliverables and outcomes. Definitely recommenda totally different type of class experience, but so meaningful and this is a project I can keep working on in the future. Awesome class tying together 2 awesome fieldsenvironment and public health.

Take it!!!
Really great opportunity to work on a real world project related to climate change, public health and/or sustainability with a lot of feedback and guidance from professors. Also has a really strong environmental justice component that is missing from a lot of other classes.

Its a ton of work, so be prepared for this to be a really heavy lift.
I would recommend this course as an opportunity to take on a project with real implications. It is exciting to be part of making something happen outside of the classroom.
This class allows you to explore a project in sustainability and climate change where you interact with many different students and can apply what is taught in the classroom in the real world.
